slides.title: Lesson 1: Periodic Behavior - Part 1
slides.content:
Trigonometric functions are periodic, meaning their values repeat at regular intervals called periods. For the main trig functions:
- $\sin(x)$ and $\cos(x)$ have a period of $360°$ (or $2\pi$ radians).
- $\tan(x)$ has a period of $180°$ (or $\pi$ radians).
The key property is that $f(x + \text{period}) = f(x)$ for any $x$. This allows us to analyze just one full cycle, as the rest repeats identically.

slides.title: Lesson 1: Periodic Behavior - Part 2
slides.content: Understanding periods is crucial because it helps predict values without calculating for every $x$. This is essential for graphing, modeling waves, and solving trig equations. Visually, you can shift or repeat a single cycle along the x-axis to understand the behavior of the function over any interval.

slides.title: Lesson 2: Graphing Sine and Cosine - Part 1
slides.content:
To graph sine and cosine functions, identify key features:
- Amplitude: $(\text{max} - \text{min})/2$, which is the height from the midline to a peak or trough.
- Midline: average of the maximum and minimum values.
- Key points for one cycle of $\sin(x)$ or $\cos(x)$: $0°, 90°, 180°, 270°, 360°$.
Always label axes and mark zeros, peaks, and troughs for clarity.

slides.title: Lesson 2: Graphing Sine and Cosine - Part 2
slides.content:
Tips for easier graphing:
- $\sin(x)$ starts at the midline and rises to the peak first.
- $\cos(x)$ starts at the peak and descends to the midline first.
- Sketch lightly at first, then add exact points for precision and clarity.

slides.title: Lesson 3: Transforming Graphs from the Equation - Part 1
slides.content:
Trig functions can be written in the form $y = A\sin(B(x-C)) + D$ or $y = A\cos(B(x-C)) + D$, where:
- $A$ determines the amplitude ($|A|$).
- $B$ determines the period ($\text{Period} = 360° / |B|$).
- $C$ is the phase shift (horizontal shift).
- $D$ is the vertical shift (midline).

slides.title: Lesson 3: Transforming Graphs from the Equation - Part 2
slides.content:
Steps to graph from an equation:
1. Draw the midline at $y = D$.
2. Apply the amplitude: move up/down from midline by $|A|$.
3. Determine the period: the length of one full cycle = $360° / |B|$.
4. Apply the phase shift: shift the graph horizontally by $C$.
5. Combine all steps to sketch the complete graph accurately.

slides.title: Lesson 4: Transforming Equations from the Graph - Part 1
slides.content:
To write a trig equation from a graph:
1. Find the amplitude: $(\text{max} - \text{min})/2$.
2. Determine the midline: $(\text{max} + \text{min})/2$.
3. Find the period: measure the length of one full cycle and calculate $B = 360° / \text{period}$.

slides.title: Lesson 4: Transforming Equations from the Graph - Part 2
slides.content:
4. Find the phase shift: horizontal shift of the starting point from the origin or midline crossing.
5. Combine all features to write $y = A\sin(B(x-C)) + D$.
6. Verify by plotting a few points to ensure the equation matches the graph accurately.

slides.title: Lesson 5: Applications of Trig Functions - Part 1
slides.content:
Trig functions model many real-world phenomena, including:
- Waves: $y = A\sin(Bx + C) + D$.
- Sound: frequency corresponds to $B$, amplitude corresponds to $A$.
- Pendulum motion: sine or cosine describes displacement over time.

slides.title: Lesson 5: Applications of Trig Functions - Part 2
slides.content:
When applying trig functions to real contexts, always identify:
- Amplitude: maximum height.
- Period: time or distance for one full cycle.
- Midline: baseline value.
Use the graph to interpret physical meaning, such as maximum displacement, oscillation frequency, or average value.
